semantic_title: Coding Guidelines for Ambulatory Surgery Encounters
section_path: Section IV > Diagnostic Coding and Reporting Guidelines for Outpatient Services > N. Ambulatory surgery

content.full_text: For ambulatory surgery, code the diagnosis for which the surgery was performed. If the postoperative diagnosis is known to be different from the preoperative diagnosis at the time the diagnosis is confirmed, select the postoperative diagnosis for coding, since it is the most definitive. (Evidence: pg no: 115, L24-L26)
content.summary: Guidelines for coding ambulatory surgery with preference for postoperative diagnosis when different from preoperative diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 115, L24-L26)
key_concepts: Ambulatory surgery diagnosis coding (Evidence: pg no: 115, L24)
Postoperative vs preoperative diagnosis priority (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25)
Most definitive diagnosis selection (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25-L26)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code the diagnosis for which the surgery was performed (Evidence: pg no: 115, L24)
detailed_rules.explanation: The primary diagnosis should reflect the condition that necessitated the surgical procedure (Evidence: pg no: 115, L24)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Select postoperative diagnosis when different from preoperative diagnosis and confirmed (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25-L26)
detailed_rules.explanation: When postoperative diagnosis differs from preoperative and is confirmed, use the postoperative diagnosis as it is most definitive (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25-L26)
detailed_rules.applies_to: ambulatory surgery encounters with differing pre/post-op diagnoses

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify encounter as ambulatory surgery
Step 2: Determine diagnosis for which surgery was performed
Step 3: Check if postoperative diagnosis differs from preoperative
Step 4: If different and confirmed, use postoperative diagnosis
Step 5: If same or postoperative not confirmed, use preoperative diagnosis

references_to.explanation: Both deal with surgical encounters but different phases of care

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient scheduled for removal of suspected malignant skin lesion, pathology reveals benign lesion
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Preoperative diagnosis: Suspected malignant neoplasm of skin. Postoperative diagnosis: Benign skin lesion confirmed by pathology.
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify as ambulatory surgery encounter

correct_coding.primary_code: D23.9 (Other benign neoplasm of skin, unspecified)
correct_coding.rationale: Postoperative diagnosis is more definitive than preoperative suspected diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25-L26)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would use suspected preoperative diagnosis instead of confirmed postoperative diagnosis
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using preoperative suspected diagnosis when postoperative diagnosis is confirmed and different

warnings: Only use postoperative diagnosis when it is confirmed and known to be different (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25)
best_practices: Always verify if postoperative diagnosis is confirmed before using it for coding (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25-L26)
Use the most definitive diagnosis available (Evidence: pg no: 115, L26)
common_mistakes: Using preoperative diagnosis when postoperative diagnosis is available and confirmed (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25-L26)
Using postoperative diagnosis when it's not yet confirmed (Evidence: pg no: 115, L25)
tips: The postoperative diagnosis takes priority because it is the most definitive (Evidence: pg no: 115, L26)
